sections.title: Data Governance of Digital Solutions – From Mapping to Managing the Project
sections.body:
Learning Objective

At the end of this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Define the role of data in modern organizations, including various types of data (quantitative, qualitative, structured, unstructured, big data, and metadata).
  • Identify the stages in the data lifecycle, from generation and collection to analysis, visualization, and interpretation, and understand the processes involved in managing data governance frameworks.

sections.title: Data
sections.body:
Data

Data consists of a set of facts, figures, words, observations, or other valuable information. By processing and analyzing this data, organizations convert raw data into meaningful insights that enhance decision-making and lead to improved business results.

sections.title: Data
sections.col1: Data plays a crucial role in various aspects of modern organizations and society as a whole. Its importance can be discussed through several key dimensions, particularly in the context of data governance frameworks. Here’s a thorough exploration of the importance of data.
sections.col2:
Decision-making

  • Informed Decision - Data provides the necessary insights that help organizations make informed decisions. By analyzing data, businesses can identify trends, forecast outcomes, and evaluate the effectiveness of their strategies.
  • Risk Management - Data helps in assessing risks and making decisions that minimize potential losses. Organizations can analyze historical data to predict future risks and implement measures to mitigate them.
sections.col3:
Operational Efficiency

  • Process Optimization - Data allows organizations to analyze their operations and identify inefficiencies. By leveraging data analytics, companies can streamline processes, reduce costs, and improve productivity.
  • Resource Allocation - Data helps in understanding resource utilization, enabling organizations to allocate resources more effectively and efficiently.

sections.title: Data
sections.col1:
Customer Insights and Engagement

  • Understanding Customer Behavior - Data analytics enables organizations to gain insights into customer preferences and behaviors. This understanding can lead to more personalized marketing strategies and improved customer satisfaction.
  • Enhancing Customer Experience - By analyzing customer feedback and interactions, organizations can enhance their products and services, leading to better customer retention and loyalty.

Regulatory Compliance and Risk Mitigation

  • Adhering to Regulations - Many industries are subject to strict regulations regarding data management and privacy. A robust data governance framework ensures compliance with these regulations, reducing the risk of legal penalties.
  • Data Security - Effective data governance frameworks help protect sensitive data from breaches and unauthorized access, thereby safeguarding the organization’s reputation and financial standing.
sections.col2:
Innovation and Competitive Advantage

  • Driving Innovation - Data can reveal gaps in the market and opportunities for innovation. Organizations that effectively leverage data can develop new products and services that meet emerging customer needs.
  • Staying Competitive - In a data-driven world, organizations that utilize data effectively can gain a competitive edge over their rivals. This can be achieved through better market analysis, customer targeting, and operational efficiencies.

Data Quality and Integrity

  • Ensuring Accuracy - High-quality data is essential for reliable analysis and decision-making. Data governance frameworks establish standards and processes for maintaining data quality and integrity.
  • Consistency Across the Organization - Data governance ensures that data is consistent across different departments and systems, facilitating better collaboration and communication.

sections.title: Data
sections.col1:
Cultural Shift Towards Data-Driven Mindset

  • Promoting Data Literacy - A strong data governance framework fosters a culture of data literacy within the organization. Employees become more adept at using data in their daily tasks, leading to a more data-driven decision-making culture.
  • Empowerment of Employees - When employees have access to accurate and timely data, they are empowered to make decisions and contribute to the organization’s success.
sections.col2:
Strategic Planning and Forecasting

  • Long-Term Planning - Data analytics provides insights that are crucial for strategic planning. Organizations can use historical data to forecast future trends and make long-term plans accordingly.
  • Performance Measurement - Data governance frameworks help organizations track their performance against set goals and objectives, enabling continuous improvement.
sections.col3: In summary, data is a vital asset for organizations, influencing every aspect of their operations, from decision-making and customer engagement to compliance and innovation. Establishing a robust data governance framework is essential to harness the full potential of data, ensuring its quality, security, and alignment with organizational goals. As organizations continue to navigate an increasingly data-driven landscape, the importance of data governance will only grow, making it a critical area of focus for leaders and stakeholders alike

sections.title: Data
sections.body:
1. Generation

Data Generation occurs daily in our increasingly digital environment. Some of this data is produced by your organization, some by your customers, and some by third parties that you may or may not know about. Every sale, purchase, hire, communication, interaction—everything generates data.

2. Collection

Data Collection is the systematic process of gathering information from various sources to answer specific research questions, test hypotheses, or evaluate outcomes.

You can collect data in a variety of ways:

  • Forms
  • Surveys
  • Interviews
  • Direct Observations

3. Processing

Data Processing is the series of actions or operations performed on collected data to convert it into a meaningful format or to extract useful information.

The various activities include:

  • Data wrangling
  • Data compression
  • Data encryption

4. Storage

Data Storage refers to the process of saving and maintaining digital information in a manner that allows for easy retrieval and management. It involves the use of various technologies and methods to hold data securely and efficiently.

sections.title: Data
sections.body:
5. Management

Data Management entails the organization, storage, and retrieval of data as needed throughout the duration of a data project. It encompasses a wide range of activities, including storage and encryption, as well as the implementation of access logs and changelogs that monitor who has accessed the data and any modifications made.

6. Analysis

Data Analysis involves processes aimed at extracting valuable insights from raw data. Analysts and data scientists employ various tools and techniques to perform these analyses. Commonly utilized methods include statistical modeling, algorithms, artificial intelligence, data mining, and machine learning.

7. Visualization

Data Visualization is the process of producing graphical representations of information, often using one or more visualization tools. By visualizing data, you can effectively convey your analysis to a broader audience, both within and outside your organization. The type of visualization you create depends on the data at hand and the narrative you wish to share.

8. Interpretation

Data Interpretation allows you to derive meaning from your analysis and visualization. This stage goes beyond merely presenting the data; it involves examining it through your expertise and insights.

sections.title: Data
sections.body:
Additional Stages in the Data Lifecycle

Data Migration

Data migration is the process of transferring data from one system, storage location, or format to another. This can occur during system upgrades, consolidations, or when moving to cloud-based solutions. The goal is to ensure that data is accurately and securely transferred while maintaining its integrity and accessibility.

Data Archiving

Data archiving involves moving inactive or infrequently accessed data to a separate storage system designed for long-term retention. This process helps free up space in primary storage systems while ensuring that important historical data remains accessible for future reference, compliance, or analysis.

Data Deletion

Data deletion is the process of permanently removing data from a storage system, making it irretrievable. This can occur when data is no longer needed, when it reaches the end of its retention period, or in compliance with data privacy regulations. Proper data deletion practices ensure that sensitive information is securely destroyed to prevent unauthorized access or recovery.

sections.title: Data Governance
sections.body:
Data Governance

Data Governance refers to the overall management of data availability, usability, integrity and security in an organization. It encompasses the policies, procedures, and standards that ensure data is managed effectively and responsibly. It is also defined as the requirements necessary to adequately govern and manage critical data assets across an organization.

sections.title: Data Governance
sections.col1: Data governance helps protect and manage large amounts of data by improving data quality, reducing data silos, enforcing compliance and security policies, and distributing data access appropriately. It is crucial for organizations for several reasons:
sections.col2:
Data Quality

  • Establishes standards and processes that enhance the accuracy, consistency, and reliability of data.
  • Maintains safe, high-quality data that is easily accessible for data discovery and business intelligence initiatives.
  • Promotes a unified approach to data management, ensuring that all departments and teams use consistent definitions and standards.

Regulatory Compliance

  • Helps ensure compliance with increasing legal requirements, avoiding potential fines and other issues.
sections.col3:
Risk Management

  • Identifies and mitigates risks associated with data management, including data breaches, loss of data integrity and unauthorized access.
  • Protects sensitive information, further helping in maintaining organizational reputation.
  • Includes creation of policies for data access and security which is vital for customer trust and safeguarding assets.

sections.title: Data Governance
sections.col1:
Enhanced Decision-Making

  • Enables better analytics and insights, leading to more informed decision-making.
  • Allows organizations to leverage data to identify trends, opportunities, and areas for improvement.

Operational Efficiency

  • Reduces redundancy and inefficiencies in data handling by establishing clear data management processes and responsibilities, further streamlining operations and improving productivity.
  • Facilitates safe data sharing across departments and with external partners, enabling collaboration and innovation while maintaining control over data usage.
sections.col2:
Digital Transformation

  • Aligns with the organization’s overall data strategy, allowing capacity for supporting initiatives such as data analytics, artificial intelligence, and other digital transformation efforts.

Stakeholder Trust

  • Builds trust with customers, partners, and regulators by demonstrating a commitment to responsible data management and ethical practices.

sections.title: Data Governance
sections.subheader: End-to-End Process of Building a Data Governance Framework
sections.col1:
1. Establish the Need for a Data Governance Program

Understanding Drivers:

  • Identify the specific reasons for implementing a data governance framework.
  • Engage people from various departments to understand their pain points.

Identifying Risks and Challenges:

  • Assess the current state of data management within the organization.
  • Highlight risks that could impact business operations and reputation in order to build a compelling case for the need of a structured framework.

Defining Objectives and Scope:

  • Define the goals of the data governance framework, such as improving data quality, ensuring compliance, or enhancing decision-making.
  • Determine the scope of the framework, including which data assets, departments, and processes will be governed.
sections.col2:
2. Determine Data Governance Maturity Level

Conducting a Maturity Assessment:

  • Evaluate the current state of the data governance practices within the organization.
  • Assess the maturity level based on criteria related to data and its respective processes.

Using a Maturity Model:

  • Utilize a data governance maturity model to categorize the organization’s current practices; common models include five levels ranging from ad-hoc practices to optimized procedures.

Identifying Gaps and Opportunities:

  • Identify gaps in current practices and opportunities for improvement based on the maturity assessment; this analysis will inform the design of the data governance framework and help prioritize initiatives that will elevate the organization’s data governance maturity.

sections.title: Data Governance
sections.subheader: End-to-End Process of Building a Data Governance Framework
sections.col1:
3. Design the Data Governance Framework

Defining Roles and Responsibilities:

  • Establish clear roles and responsibilities including data owners, data stewards, and governance committees; this will ensure accountability and facilitate effective data management.

Creating Policies and Standards:

  • Develop comprehensive data governance policies and standards that address data quality, security, privacy, and access; policies should align with organizational goals and regulatory requirements.

Establishing Processes and Workflows:

  • Design processes for data lifecycle management.
  • Define workflows for identifying and resolving data issues, ensuring that data governance practices are integrated into daily operations.

Implementing Technology Solutions:

  • Identify and implement technology solutions that support data governance initiatives, such as data catalogs, quality tools, and compliance monitoring systems.
sections.col2:
4. Establish an Approach to Sustain Data Governance Initiatives

Developing a Communication Strategy:

  • Create a communication plan to keep stakeholders informed about initiatives, policies, and changes; regular updates and transparency foster engagement and buy-in from employees and other stakeholders.

Providing Training and Support:

  • Offer training programs to educate employees about data governance principles, policies, and their roles in data management.
  • Equip staff with the knowledge and skills needed to adhere to the governance practices.

Monitoring and Measuring Success:

  • Establish metrics and KPIs to monitor the effectiveness of the data governance program.
  • Regularly assess progress against objectives and adjust whenever necessary.

Fostering a Data-Driven Culture:

  • Encourage a culture that values data as a strategic asset.
  • Engage leadership to champion data governance efforts and promote responsible data usage.
  • Recognize and reward good data management practices to reinforce the importance of data governance.

sections.title: Data Governance of Digital Solutions – From Mapping to Managing the Project
sections.body:
Learning Objective

At the end of this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Identify and describe key components of a data governance framework
  • Compare and contrast different data governance frameworks and their applicability to various organizational contexts

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
Process, policies, and standards form the backbone of an organization’s data governance, providing a framework for how data is managed, accessed, and protected within an organization. These set the rules for managing data within an organization, ensuring that process, policies, and standards are practical and useful. The six data governance policy types are as follows:

Data Quality Policy

  • Guarantees that your data is suitable for its intended use by monitoring quality metrics, including validity, completeness, timeliness, accuracy, and integrity.

Data Privacy Policy

  • Creates accountability and transparent data management practices to reduce privacy risks and ensure compliance with regulations.
sections.col2:
Data Security Policy

  • Controls access to critical information to mitigate the risk of security breaches.

Data Lifecycle Policy

  • Establishes guidelines for data retention, archiving, and deletion.

Data Ethics Policy

  • Ensures that your data management, utilization, and collaboration practices are in harmony with your organization’s values and ethics.

Data Definitions and Models

  • Establishes uniformity in key concepts, master data domains, and vital business KPIs across your organization, ensuring that everyone communicates in a consistent manner.

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.body: Setting up data governance policies involves several key steps:

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
The human element is crucial in data governance as it involves the roles, responsibilities, and structure that support effective data management. A best practice data governance model typically includes three organizational components:

Data Governance Office (DGO)

  • Defines policies and standards
  • Empower data leader in the domains with tools, playbook, and training
  • Ensure coordination and consistency across domain and key roles in the data lifecycle
  • Link data governance efforts to technology
  • Provides targeted support for issues
sections.col2:
Data Council

  • Owns strategic direction and principles
  • Proposes DGO structure, defines domains and assigns leaders
  • Confirms adherence to standards and policies
  • Review progress on initiatives and serves as funding gateway
  • Resolves and/or escalates issues
  • Chaired by the Head of DGO

Data Leader by Domain

  • Sets and executes strategy of their domains according to business priorities
  • Understand and meet needs of data consumers
  • Owns and manages their data, assesses and improve data quality, defines definitions and data model, etc.
  • Participates in data council

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
Below is a detailed list of key roles involved in data governance, to be followed by their respective responsibilities:

Data Governance Officer (DGO)

The DGO is responsible for the overall management and implementation of the data governance framework within the organization.

Data Governance Committee

This committee is composed of senior leaders from various departments and oversees the data governance program.

Data Owners

Data Owners are responsible for specific data domains within the organization, ensuring the accuracy, security, and appropriate use of data.
sections.col2:
Data Stewards

Data Stewards are responsible for the day-to-day management of data within their respective departments.

IT Security Officer

The IT Security Officer is responsible for implementing and maintaining data security measures to protect sensitive information.

Compliance Officer

The Compliance Officer ensures that the organization adheres to legal and regulatory requirements related to data management.

Legal Advisor

The Legal Advisor provides legal guidance on data governance policies and practices.

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
Below is a detailed list of key roles involved in data governance, to be followed by their respective responsibilities:

Data Governance Officer (DGO)

  • Develop and enforce data governance policies and procedures.
  • Ensure compliance with relevant regulations
  • Coordinate data governance activities across various departments.
  • Act as the primary point of contact for data governance issues and initiatives.
  • Facilitate training and awareness programs related to data governance.
  • Monitor and report on the effectiveness of data governance practices.
sections.col2:
Data Governance Committee

  • Provide strategic direction and support for data governance initiatives.
  • Review and approve data governance policies and standards.
  • Ensure alignment of data governance with organizational goals and objectives.
  • Facilitate cross-departmental collaboration and communication regarding data governance.
  • Address any escalated data governance issues that require executive attention.
sections.col3:
Data Owners

  • Define data quality standards and policies for their respective data domains.
  • Ensure that data is used in compliance with organizational policies and regulations.
  • Oversee data access and usage within their departments.
  • Collaborate with Data Stewards to monitor data quality and address issues.
  • Serve as the point of contact for data-related inquiries within their domain.

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
Data Stewards

  • Ensure adherence to data governance policies and procedures.
  • Monitor data quality metrics and report any discrepancies or issues.
  • Facilitate data access and usage for authorized personnel.
  • Collaborate with Data Owners to implement data quality improvement initiatives.
  • Serve as liaisons between Data Owners and other stakeholders to resolve data-related issues.
sections.col2:
Compliance Officer

  • Monitor compliance with data protection regulations
  • Conduct audits and assessments to evaluate compliance with data governance policies.
  • Provide guidance on data protection practices and policies.
  • Develop and implement training programs related to compliance and data privacy.
  • Report compliance status and issues to the Data Governance Committee and senior management.

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
IT Security Officer

  • Develop and enforce data security policies and procedures.
  • Conduct risk assessments to identify vulnerabilities in data systems.
  • Oversee cybersecurity protocols and incident response plans.
  • Monitor data access and usage to detect unauthorized access or breaches.
  • Collaborate with Data Owners and Data Stewards to ensure data security measures are integrated into data management practices.
sections.col2:
Legal Advisor

  • Ensure that data governance policies comply with relevant laws and regulations.
  • Assist in drafting data governance policies and procedures.
  • Provide legal advice on data protection and privacy issues.
  • Address legal concerns related to data management and usage.
  • Support the Compliance Officer in ensuring adherence to legal requirements.

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
What is the leading practice and model out of the four?

Hybrid and Balanced

This data governance model is considered the leading practice as it allows distribution of data control between centralized data organization and business units including data domain owners, system owners, and technical data stewards.

It is the leading practice for several reasons:

  • Flexibility - It enables organizations to customize their governance approach to meet the specific needs of business units, ensuring relevant and effective practices.
  • Balance of Control and Autonomy - Organizations can control data governance while empowering departments to manage their own data through a balance of centralized oversight and decentralized decision-making.
  • Improved Collaboration - It promotes collaboration between IT and business units, encouraging cross-functional teams to work together on data governance initiatives.
  • Enhanced Data Quality and Compliance - A balanced approach enforces consistent data governance policies while allowing local adaptations to meet industry standards and regulations.
sections.col2:
• Stakeholder Engagement - It encourages stakeholder involvement in governance, fostering a culture of data responsibility and incorporating diverse perspectives in decisions.
  • Adaptability to Change - The model is more adaptable to changes in technology, business processes, and regulatory requirements.
  • Focus on Business Value - By integrating governance into business processes, the model emphasizes the importance of data as a strategic asset.

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.body:
The technology aspect of data governance encompasses the tools and systems that will support digital transformation and data-related initiatives. To uphold data integrity, organizations should invest in data management solutions that promote efficient data entry, workflow oversight, and data security.

With the help of appropriate tools and technology, it will be more efficient to:

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
Business Enabling Tools of Technology

Information Systems

These are organized systems for collecting, storing, managing, and processing data and information. The different types can include:

  • Transaction Processing
  • Design Support
  • Executive Information
  • Customer Relationship Management
  • Enterprise Resource Planning
  • Geographic Information
Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning

The simulation of human intelligence processes by computer systems used in various fields, including healthcare (diagnosis and treatment recommendations), finance (fraud detection and risk assessment), customer service (chatbots and virtual assistants), and autonomous vehicles (navigation and obstacle detection).

Other Tools and Technology

Other business enabling tools can include collaboration, project management, data analytics, cloud, automation, and cybersecurity tools.
sections.col2:
Aside from business enabling tools, the following are banking and financial technology trends for 2025:

Blockchain Technology

Blockchain technology is a decentralized digital ledger that records transactions across multiple computers in a way that ensures the security and transparency of data. Its impact on banking and finance include:

  • Enhanced Security - The cryptographic features of blockchain make it difficult for unauthorized parties to alter transaction data, reducing fraud risk.
  • Faster Transactions - It can facilitate real-time settlement of transactions, especially in cross-border payments, reducing the time and cost associated with traditional processes.
  • Smart Contracts - These self-executing contracts with the terms directly written into code can automate and streamline various financial agreements, reducing the need for intermediaries.
sections.col3:
Internet of Things (IoT) in Finance

The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the network of interconnected devices that communicate and exchange data over the internet. Its impact on banking and finance include:

  • Data-Driven Insights - Financial institutions can leverage data from IoT devices to gain insights into customer behavior, preferences, and spending patterns, enabling personalized services.
  • Risk Management - IoT devices can help monitor assets in real-time, providing banks with valuable data for risk assessment and management.
  • Enhanced Customer Experience - IoT can facilitate seamless payment experiences, such as using smartwatches or connected cars for transactions.

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
Open Banking

Open banking is a system that allows third-party developers to build applications and services around financial institutions, using APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) to access customer data (with consent). Its impact on banking and finance include:

  • Increased Competition - Open banking fosters competition by enabling new entrants (FinTechs) to offer innovative financial products and services.
  • Customer Empowerment - Customers gain more control over their financial data and can choose services that best meet their needs.
  • Enhanced Innovation - Banks can collaborate with FinTechs to develop new services, improving customer experience and operational efficiency.
sections.col2:
Cloud Computing

Cloud computing refers to the delivery of computing services (such as storage, processing power, and applications) over the internet. Its impact on banking and finance include:

  • Scalability - Cloud solutions allow financial institutions to scale their operations quickly and efficiently, adapting to changing market demands.
  • Cost Efficiency - By reducing the need for on-premises infrastructure, banks can lower operational costs and invest more in innovation.
  • Data Analytics - Cloud computing enables advanced data analytics capabilities, allowing banks to derive insights from large datasets for better decision-making.
sections.col3:
Biometric Authentication

Biometric authentication uses unique biological characteristics (such as fingerprints, facial recognition, or iris scans) to verify a person's identity. Its impact on banking and finance include:

  • Enhanced Security - Biometric authentication provides a higher level of security compared to traditional passwords, reducing the risk of identity theft and fraud.
  • Improved User Experience - Customers benefit from faster and more convenient authentication processes, leading to a better overall experience.
  • Regulatory Compliance - As regulations around data security tighten, biometric authentication can help financial institutions meet compliance requirements.

sections.title: The PPT Framework
sections.col1:
Fintech Partnerships

Collaboration between traditional financial institutions and FinTech companies is becoming increasingly common as banks seek to leverage innovative technologies. Its impact on banking and finance include:

  • Innovation Acceleration - Partnerships allow banks to quickly adopt new technologies and services without the need for extensive in-house development.
  • Expanded Offerings - By collaborating with FinTechs, banks can enhance their product offerings, providing customers with a wider range of financial services
  • Agility and Responsiveness - FinTech partnerships enable banks to respond more rapidly to market changes and customer demands.
sections.col2:
Regulatory Technology (RegTech)

Regulatory Technology (RegTech) refers to the use of technology to help financial institutions comply with regulations efficiently and effectively. Its impact on banking and finance include:

  • Cost Reduction - RegTech solutions can automate compliance processes, reducing the time and resources required to meet regulatory requirements.
  • Real-Time Monitoring - RegTech tools enable real-time monitoring of transactions and activities, helping banks identify and address compliance issues proactively.
  • Enhanced Reporting - Automated reporting capabilities streamline the process of generating compliance reports, ensuring accuracy and timeliness.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.body: A logical structure for classifying, organizing, and communicating complex activities involved in making decisions about and taking action on enterprise data.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.body:
Mission and Value

The mission of every data governance program should be to deliver value to the organization. The following are factors to consider in order to shape a successful program:

  • Existing Governance
  • Existing Management
  • Expectations for the Program
  • Governance Lenses
  • Governance Culture

Beneficiaries

Your data governance program should provide value to your organization’s products, services, processes, capabilities, and assets. This value can take the form of:

  • The data itself
  • Data products
  • Policy and rules
  • Checkpoints and controls
  • Communities, advocates, and experts
  • Decision-making

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.body:
Data Products

Reusable assets that are designed for a specific purpose, often used by teams across the organization. These may be presented as dashboards, analytics models, data models, datasets, data feeds, etc., with respective data usage and sharing instructions and applicable compliance requirements.

Controls

In handling data, risk management strategies must be operationalized. Controls can be preventative or detective/corrective, such as process controls or technical controls, automated, manual, or technology-enabled manual processes.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.body:
Accountabilities

After implementing rules, departmental responsibilities should be considered in the data governance program to further define accountabilities. Governance efforts involve cross-functional teams. It is good to have respective governance coordinators in order to effectively cascade the organization’s protocols, updates, and news.

Decision Rights

The data governance program must facilitate, document, store, and make available who made what decisions, and when.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.body:
Policy and Rules

Data governance programs must define data-related policies, serving as translators between business teams, legal teams, and technical teams that must interpret policy and act upon it. Understandable language can help teams understand high-level statements and identify implications for products, services, processes, capabilities, and assets.

Processes, Tools, and Communications

Valuable outputs are produced by executing Data Governance processes, by using tools, and through communications that demonstrate its benefits:

Processes must be standardized, documented, and repeatable.

Tools are needed to manage the program and its outputs, engage your stakeholders, capture metrics and demonstrate value, and document and share policy and decisions.

Communications in data governance will need strong capabilities in written, graphical, and verbal communication skills to ensure effective, clear, and objective communication.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.body:
Data Work Program

Many programs employ a portfolio approach to organizing their work, grouping projects and ongoing activities into workstreams. Each workstream will typically have its own lifecycle, focus, scope, goals, metrics, funding, and responsibilities.

Participants

Identify a data governance office (DGO) that will facilitate and support data governance and data stewardship activities. Some organizations assign a person or a team to be dedicated to the responsibilities of a DGO.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.col1:
The DAMA-DMBOK (Data Management Body of Knowledge) is a comprehensive framework developed by the DAMA (Data Management Association) that outlines best practices, principles, and guidelines for effective data management.

DAMA-DMBOK Functional Framework Version 3 10 Data Management Functions:

  • Data Governance - planning, supervision, and control over data management and use
  • Data Architecture Management - as an integral part of enterprise architecture
  • Data Development - analysis, design, building, testing, deployment, and maintenance
  • Database Operations Management - support for structured physical data assets
  • Data Security Management - ensuring privacy, confidentiality, and appropriate access
sections.col2:
• Reference & Master Data Management - managing golden versions and replicas
  • Data Warehousing & Business Intelligence Management - enabling access to decision support data for reporting and analysis
  • Document & Content Management - storing, protecting, indexing, and enabling access to data found in unstructured sources (electronic files and physical records)
  • Meta Data Management - integrating, controlling, and delivering meta data
  • Data Quality Management - defining, monitoring, and improving data quality

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.col1:
DAMA-DMBOK Functional Framework Version 3 Seven Environmental Elements:

  • Goals & Principles -The directional business goals of each function and fundamental principles that guide performance of each function.
  • Activities - Each function is further decomposed into lower-level activities. Some activities are grouped into sub-functions and can be further decomposed into tasks and steps.
  • Deliverables - The information and physical databases and documents created as interim and final outputs of each functions.
  • Roles & Responsibilities - The business and IT roles involved in performing and supervising the function and the specific responsibilities of each role in that function.
sections.col2:
• Practices & Procedures - Common and popular methods and techniques used to perform the processes and produce the deliverables. May also include common conventions, best practice recommendations, and alternative approaches without elaboration.
  • Technology - Categories of supporting technology, standards and protocols, product selection criteria, and common learning curves.
  • Organization & Culture - These issues might include management metrics, success factors, reporting structures, group dynamics, cultural-related factors, etc.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.body:
The COSO Internal Control Framework helps companies visualize various dimensions of internal control. Internal controls must be implemented to ensure proper data governance.

  • The top face of the cube illustrates why internal controls are needed. Internal controls over data governance are necessary for operations, reporting, and compliance.
  • The right face of the cube illustrates where we need internal control. Internal controls over data governance should be implemented at all levels of the organization.
  • The front face of the cube illustrates how organizations can have good internal controls, or what components must be in place.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.col1:
There are five essential components to the COSO internal control framework:/p>

Control Environment

  • Principle 1 - Demonstrate commitment to integrity and ethical values
  • Principle 2 - Exercises oversight responsibility
  • Principle 3 - Establish structure, authority, and responsibility
  • Principle 4 - Demonstrates commitment to competencies
  • Principle 5 - Enforces accountability
sections.col2:
Risk Assessment

  • Principle 6 - Specifies suitable objectives
  • Principle 7 - Identifies and analyzes risk
  • Principle 8 - Assesses fraud risk
  • Principle 9 - Identifies and analyzes significant change

Control Activities

  • Principle 10 - Selects and develops control activities
  • Principle 11 - Selects and develops general controls over technology
  • Principle 12 - Deploys through policies and procedures
sections.col3:
Information & Communication

  • Principle 13 - Uses relevant information
  • Principle 14 - Communicates internally
  • Principle 15 - Communicates externally

Monitoring Activities

  • Principle 16 - Conducts ongoing and/or separate evaluations
  • Principle 17 - Evaluates and communicates deficiencies

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.body: COBIT 2019 is a framework designed for the governance and management of enterprise information and technology. It provides a comprehensive set of practices, tools, and resources to help organizations achieve their objectives by aligning IT with business goals.

sections.title: Relevant Frameworks
sections.col1:
The six (6) principles are the core requirements for a governance system for enterprise information and technology.

Provide Stakeholder Value

  • Each enterprise needs a governance system to satisfy stakeholder needs and to generate value from the use of I&T.

Holistic Approach

  • A governance system for enterprise I&T is built from a number of components that can be of different types and that work together in a holistic way.
sections.col2:
Dynamic Governance System

  • A governance system should be dynamic. This means that each time one or more of the design factors are changed the impact of these changes on the Enterprise Governance of Information and Technology (EGIT) system must be considered.

Governance Distinct from Management

  • A governance system should clearly distinguish between governance and management activities and structures.
sections.col3:
Tailored to Enterprise Needs

  • A governance system should be tailored to the enterprise’s needs, using a set of design factors as parameters to customize and prioritize the governance system components.

End-to-End Governance System

  • A governance system should cover the enterprise end to end, focusing not only on the IT function but on all technology and information processing the enterprise puts in place to achieve its goals.

sections.title: Case Study
sections.body: Rural Bank XYZ, located in a small town in the Philippines, has been serving its community for over 30 years. With the increasing demand for digital banking services, the bank has decided to undergo a digital transformation to improve customer experience, streamline operations, and comply with the Philippine Data Privacy Act of 2012. The bank's leadership recognizes that a robust data governance framework is essential to support this transformation.

sections.title: Case Study
sections.col1:
End-to-End Process of Building a Data Governance Framework

1. Establish the need for a data governance program
Understanding the Drivers

Identify Specific Reasons

  • Customers are increasingly requesting online banking services
  • Regulatory compliance is critical, especially with the Philippine Data Privacy Act

Engage Departments

  • Conduct interviews with the IT department, customer service representatives, and compliance officers to understand their challenges with current data management practices, such as data silos and inconsistent data quality.
sections.col2:
Identifying Risks and Challenges

Assess Current State

  • A data audit reveals that customer data is stored in multiple systems, leading to inconsistencies and potential compliance risks.

Highlight Risks

  • Risks identified include potential data breaches due to inadequate security measures, non-compliance fines, and reputational damage from poor customer service experiences.
sections.col3:
Defining Objectives and Scope

Define Goals

  • Improve data quality to ensure accurate customer information.
  • Ensure compliance with the Data Privacy Act by implementing proper data handling and protection protocols.
  • Enhance decision-making capabilities through better data analytics.

Determine Scope

  • The framework will govern customer data, transaction data, and operational data across all departments, including IT, Operations, Marketing, and Compliance.

sections.title: Case Study
sections.col1:
End-to-End Process of Building a Data Governance Framework

2. Determine Data Governance Maturity Level
Conducting a Maturity Assessment

Evaluate Current Practices

  • A survey is conducted among employees to assess their understanding of data governance practices, revealing a low level of awareness and inconsistent practices.
sections.col2:
Using a Maturity Model

Categorize Practices

  • The bank is classified at Level 2 (Managed) of the five-level maturity model, indicating that while some processes are in place, they are not consistently applied across the organization.
sections.col3:
Identifying Gaps and Opportunities

Identify Gaps

  • Gaps include a lack of defined data ownership, insufficient data quality controls, and inadequate training on data privacy regulations.

sections.title: Case Study
sections.col1:
End-to-End Process of Building a Data Governance Framework

3. Design the Data Governance Framework
Defining Roles and Responsibilities

Establish Roles

  • Appoint a Data Governance Officer (DGO) responsible for overseeing the data governance program.
  • Designate Data Owners for customer data (Head of Customer Service) and transaction data (Head of Operations).
  • Assign Data Stewards in each department to ensure adherence to data governance policies.
Creating Policies and Standards

Develop Policies

  • Create a Data Governance Policy that includes guidelines for data collection, processing, storage, and sharing, ensuring alignment with the Data Privacy Act.
  • Establish a Data Quality Policy that outlines standards for data accuracy, completeness, and consistency.
sections.col2:
Establishing Processes and Workflows

Design Processes

  • Implement a data lifecycle management process that includes data classification, access control, and data retention schedules.
  • Define workflows for reporting and resolving data quality issues, ensuring that Data Stewards are responsible for monitoring data quality metrics.
Implementing Technology Solutions

Identify Technology

  • Invest in a data governance tool that includes a data catalog for tracking data assets, a data quality monitoring system, and a compliance management platform to ensure adherence to data privacy regulations.

sections.title: Case Study
sections.col1:
End-to-End Process of Building a Data Governance Framework

4. Establish an Approach to Sustain Data Governance Initiatives
Developing a Communication Strategy

Create a Communication Plan

  • Develop a monthly newsletter to update stakeholders on data governance initiatives, share success stories, and highlight upcoming training sessions.
sections.col2:
Providing Training and Support

Offer Training Programs

  • Conduct quarterly training sessions for all employees on data governance principles, data privacy laws, and their specific roles in data management.
Monitoring and Measuring Success

Establish Metrics

  • Define KPIs such as the percentage of data accuracy, the number of data breaches reported, and employee training completion rates.
sections.col3:
Fostering a Data-Driven Culture

Encourage Data Valuation

  • Launch an internal campaign to promote the importance of data as a strategic asset, featuring testimonials from leadership on the value of data governance.

sections.title: Case Study
sections.col1:
Role Descriptions

Board of Directors

Provides overall governance and strategic direction for the organization. They ensure that data governance aligns with the bank's mission and objectives and are responsible for approving major data governance policies and initiatives.

Data Governance Committee

Composed of senior leaders from various departments, this committee oversees the data governance program, reviews policies, and ensures alignment with organizational goals. They provide guidance and support to the Data Governance Officer.
sections.col2:
Data Governance Officer

Responsible for the overall management and implementation of the data governance framework. This role involves developing data governance policies, ensuring compliance with regulations, and coordinating activities across departments. The DGO acts as the primary point of contact for data governance issues.

Data Owners

Responsible for specific data domains within the organization:

  • Head of Customer Service (Customer Data)
  • Head of Operations (Transaction Data)
  • Head of IT (IT Data)
  • Head of Risk Management (Risk Data)
  • Head of Finance (Financial Data)
sections.col3:
Data Stewards

Responsible for the day-to-day management of data within their respective departments, serving as liaisons between data owners and the rest of the organization:

  • Customer Service Data Steward
  • Operations Data Steward
  • IT Data Steward
  • Risk Data Steward
  • Financial Data Steward
Compliance Officer

Ensures adherence to legal and regulatory requirements related to data management, including the Philippine Data Privacy Act of 2012. This role involves monitoring compliance, conducting audits, and providing guidance on data protection practices.

IT Security Officer

Responsible for implementing and maintaining data security measures to protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and breaches. This role involves overseeing cybersecurity protocols and conducting risk assessments.

Legal Advisor

Provides legal guidance on data governance policies and practices, ensuring compliance with relevant laws and regulations. The Legal Advisor assists in drafting governance policies and addressing legal issues related to data management.

sections.title: To thrive in the age of digital transformation, mastering data governance is an essential skill.
sections.body: Digital transformation has become a vital necessity for maintaining competitiveness in today’s market. Organizations across various sectors are leveraging technology and data-driven strategies to transform their operations, products, and services. Yet, amid this digital evolution, one crucial element that is often overlooked is data governance.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.body: The System Development Lifecycle (SDLC) is a structured approach to developing information systems, encompassing various phases from planning and analysis to design, implementation, and maintenance. It ensures that data management practices are integrated throughout the development process.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
System Analysis

An evaluative process to assess user needs, resource requirements, benefits, and costs. Understanding the end goals and uses of the system is important to ensure its proper design and to assess system feasibility. Its activities involve:

  • Gathering of requirements
  • Assessing the feasibility of the proposed system
Conceptual Design

The process of creating plans for meeting the needs of the organization. Often, several designs will be considered at this stage. Organizations will weigh the costs and benefits of each design before selecting one design. Its activities involve:

  • Defining the overall architecture of the system
  • Developing models to visualize how the system will function and interact with users and other systems
  • Creating wireframes or prototypes of the user interface
Physical Design

The process of identifying the features, specifications, and equipment. Consideration is given both to the end-user experience and to the backend computational and processing power need. Its activities involve:

  • Specifying hardware and software requirements
  • Finalizing the user interface design from layouts, navigation, and accessibility features
sections.col2:
Implementation and Conversion

The process of making the system design a reality. This will take a considerable amount of time, as both hardware and software will involve installation and testing to ensure proper functionality. Its activities involve:

  • Writing the code for the system
  • Conducting various testing phases
  • Planning and executing the transition from the old to the new system
Operations and Maintenance

The process of fine-tuning and refining the system as users explore functionalities and place demands on the system processing. One important component of this step is to identify and authorize users that will have access to various components of the system. Its activities involve:

  • Monitoring system performance, user feedback, and data integrity to ensure the system operates effectively
  • Addressing issues and possible enhancements based on user needs and changing requirements
  • Maintaining documentation for system changes, user manuals, and operational procedures.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
Enterprise Architecture (EA) is a strategic framework that defines the structure and operation of an organization. It provides a holistic view of the organization’s processes, information systems, technologies, and data, aligning them with business goals and objectives.

In the context of data governance, enterprise architecture plays a crucial role in ensuring that data is managed effectively, securely, and in compliance with regulations.

Alignment of Business and IT Goals

EA ensures that data governance initiatives are aligned with the overall business strategy and objectives.

Activities:

  • Involve key stakeholders from all key departments
  • Develop a governance framework that outlines roles, responsibilities, and processes for managing data across the organization
sections.col2:
Data Architecture

EA provides a blueprint for data architecture, which is essential for effective data governance.

Activities:

  • Create clear data models that define data entities, relationships and attributes
  • Establish data standards and policies to ensure quality, consistency, and interoperability
sections.col3:
Integration of Data Sources

EA facilitates the integration of disparate data sources, which is critical for comprehensive data governance.

Activities:

  • Define strategies for integrating data from various sources
  • Implement data lineage tracking to understand the flow of data across systems

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
Stakeholders, including employees, customers, partners, and regulators, play a vital role in shaping the direction and outcomes of digital transformation efforts. Data governance serves as a foundational element that can significantly enhance stakeholder management by ensuring that data is accurate, accessible, and secure. This discussion explores how data governance can be leveraged to improve stakeholder engagement during digital transformation.


Establishing Trust and Transparency
  • Data Integrity - Robust data governance frameworks ensure that the data used in decision-making is accurate and reliable. When stakeholders trust the data, they are more likely to engage positively with the transformation process.
  • Transparency in Data Usage - Clear policies regarding data collection, usage, and sharing foster transparency. Stakeholders are more inclined to participate when they understand how their data will be used and protected.
sections.col2:
Facilitating Communication and Collaboration
  • Centralized Data Access - A well-defined data governance framework provides stakeholders with centralized access to relevant data. This accessibility promotes collaboration and informed discussions among stakeholders.
  • Feedback Mechanisms - Implementing data governance allows organizations to establish feedback loops where stakeholders can share their insights and concerns. This two-way communication enhances engagement and fosters a sense of ownership.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
Stakeholders, including employees, customers, partners, and regulators, play a vital role in shaping the direction and outcomes of digital transformation efforts. Data governance serves as a foundational element that can significantly enhance stakeholder management by ensuring that data is accurate, accessible, and secure. This discussion explores how data governance can be leveraged to improve stakeholder engagement during digital transformation.


Enhancing Decision-Making
  • Data-Driven Insights - Data governance ensures that stakeholders have access to high-quality data analytics. By leveraging these insights, stakeholders can make informed decisions that align with the organization’s goals.
  • Alignment with Stakeholder Interests - Understanding stakeholder needs through data analysis allows organizations to tailor their digital transformation strategies. This alignment increases stakeholder buy-in and support.
sections.col2:
Empowering Stakeholders through Data Literacy
  • Training and Education - Data governance initiatives can include training programs that enhance stakeholders' data literacy. Empowering stakeholders with the skills to understand and utilize data fosters greater engagement.
  • Encouraging Data-Driven Culture - Promoting a culture that values data-driven decision-making encourages stakeholders to actively participate in the transformation process. When stakeholders feel equipped to contribute, their engagement levels rise.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
Effective risk management is essential for navigating digital transformation risks such as data breaches, compliance issues, and operational inefficiencies. This discussion explores how data governance can be leveraged to enhance risk management during digital transformation initiatives.


Establishing a Strong Data Governance Framework
  • Data Stewardship - Appointing data stewards responsible for overseeing data quality, integrity, and security. These individuals ensure that data is accurate and reliable, which is crucial for informed risk assessments.
  • Data Policies and Standards - Developing clear policies regarding data collection, usage, and sharing. These policies help mitigate risks associated with data misuse and ensure compliance with regulations.
sections.col2:
Identifying and Assessing Risks
  • Centralized Data Access - A well-defined data governance framework provides stakeholders with centralized access to relevant data. This accessibility promotes collaboration and informed discussions among stakeholders.
  • Feedback Mechanisms - Implementing data governance allows organizations to establish feedback loops where stakeholders can share their insights and concerns. This two-way communication enhances engagement and fosters a sense of ownership.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
Effective risk management is essential for navigating digital transformation risks such as data breaches, compliance issues, and operational inefficiencies. This discussion explores how data governance can be leveraged to enhance risk management during digital transformation initiatives.


Enhancing Compliance and Regulatory Adherence
  • Regulatory Monitoring - Establishing processes to monitor changes in regulations and ensure that data governance policies are updated accordingly. This proactive approach helps organizations stay compliant and avoid penalties.
  • Audit Trails - Implementing audit trails that track data access and usage. These trails provide transparency and accountability, making it easier to demonstrate compliance during audits.
sections.col2:
Mitigating Data Security Risks
  • Access Controls - Establishing strict access controls to ensure that only authorized personnel can access sensitive data. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access and data breaches.
  • Data Encryption and Masking - Implementing data encryption and masking techniques to protect sensitive information. These measures help safeguard data both at rest and in transit.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
Effective risk management is essential for navigating digital transformation risks such as data breaches, compliance issues, and operational inefficiencies. This discussion explores how data governance can be leveraged to enhance risk management during digital transformation initiatives.


Promoting a Risk-Aware Culture
  • Training and Education - Providing training programs that educate employees about data governance policies, data security best practices, and the importance of risk management. Empowered employees are more likely to recognize and report potential risks.
  • Encouraging Reporting - Creating an environment where employees feel comfortable reporting data-related risks and incidents. Open communication channels facilitate timely responses to emerging threats.
sections.col2:
Continuous Monitoring and Improvement
  • Key Risk Indicators (KRIs) - Establishing KRIs that provide insights into potential risks. By monitoring these indicators, organizations can detect early warning signs and take proactive measures.
  • Regular Audits and Reviews - Conducting regular audits and reviews of data governance practices to identify areas for improvement. This iterative approach ensures that risk management strategies remain effective and relevant.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
In today's digital landscape, information security is a critical component of an organization's overall risk management strategy, particularly as organizations undergo digital transformation. As data governance frameworks are established to manage data effectively, information security plays a vital role in protecting that data from threats and vulnerabilities. This discussion explores the connection between information security, data governance, and risk management, highlighting how they work together to safeguard organizational assets.


Understanding Information Security

Information Security…

  • is the processes and practices designed to protect sensitive information from unauthorized access, disclosure, alteration, and destruction.
  • encompasses a wide range of measures, including physical security, network security, application security, and data protection.
sections.col2:
Key Objectives of Information Security
  • Confidentiality - Ensuring that sensitive information is accessible only to authorized individuals.
  • Integrity - Maintaining the accuracy and completeness of data, preventing unauthorized modifications.
  • Availability - Ensuring that information and resources are accessible to authorized users when needed.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
The Role of Information Security in Data Governance

Information security is integral to effective data governance, as it provides the necessary safeguards to protect data throughout its lifecycle. Here are some key connections:


Data Protection Policies

Information security complements policies established by data governance frameworks by defining security measures that protect data from breaches and unauthorized access.

Data governance may dictate how customer data is collected and stored, while information security outlines how that data should be encrypted.
sections.col2:
Risk Assessment and Management

Data governance frameworks facilitate the risk identification and assessment associated with data management while information security enhances this process by providing tools and methodologies for assessing security risks.
sections.col3:
Regulatory Adherence

Many industries are subject to strict regulations regarding data protection and privacy (e.g. Philippine Data Privacy Act of 2012). Information security along with data governance frameworks practices ensure that organizations comply with these regulations by implementing necessary controls and safeguards.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.col1:
Enhancing Risk Management through Information Security

Effective risk management requires a holistic approach that integrates data governance and information security. Here’s how information security contributes to risk management:


Access Controls

Information security establishes strict access controls to ensure that only authorized personnel can access sensitive data. This reduces the risk of data breaches and unauthorized access. Data governance frameworks can define roles and responsibilities for data access, while information security enforces these controls through technologies such as role-based access control (RBAC).
sections.col2:
Incident Response and Recovery

Information security includes incident response plans that outline how to respond to data breaches and security incidents. These plans are essential for minimizing the impact of security threats. Data governance frameworks can provide guidelines for reporting incidents and ensuring that data handling practices are followed during a security event.
sections.col3:
Continuous Monitoring

Information security involves continuous monitoring of systems and networks to detect potential threats and vulnerabilities. This approach complements data governance by ensuring that data management practices are regularly assessed for security risks. Organizations can establish KRIs related to information security to monitor potential threats.

sections.title: Data Governance in Digital Transformation
sections.body: Information security is a vital component of data governance and risk management, particularly in the context of digital transformation. By integrating information security practices with data governance, organizations can effectively protect their data assets from threats and vulnerabilities. This holistic approach also fosters a culture of security awareness that empowers employees to contribute to the organization's overall security posture. As organizations continue to navigate the complexities of digital transformation, the synergy between data governance and information security will be essential for safeguarding sensitive information and achieving strategic objectives.

sections.subheader: Sample Data Governance Policy for Rural Banks
sections.col1:
Data Governance Policy for Rural Banks

I. Preliminary Provisions
Section 1. Objectives

This Data Governance Policy aims to:

  • Define the roles and responsibilities for different data usage and establish a clear framework of accountability.
  • Develop best practices for effective data management and protection.
  • Ensure that data used by the rural bank in its decision-making, reporting, and planning is complete, accurate, and unaltered.
  • Ensure compliance with applicable laws, regulations, and standards, including the Data Privacy Act of 2012, and mitigate compliance risks.
  • Ensure that a data trail is effectively documented within the processes associated with accessing, retrieving, reporting, managing, and storing data.
sections.col2:
Section 2. Applicability

This Policy applies to all employees, officers, and third-party service providers of the rural bank who handle data in any form.
sections.col3:
Section 3. Definition of Terms

For the purpose of this Policy, the following terms are defined as follows:

  • Access: Refers to the finding, retrieval, or use of data.
  • Data Subject: Refers to individuals whose personal information is processed by the rural bank.
  • Documents: Refers to forms, templates, records, lists, tables, reports, issuances, invoices, receipts, or other documents that contain personal information of data subjects, whether in printed or electronic format.
  • Private Information: Refers to personal and confidential data as defined in the Data Privacy Act of 2012.
  • Sensitive Personal Information: Refers to personal data that may cause harm or distress to the data subject if disclosed.

sections.title: Best Practices of Organizations
sections.subheader: Sample Data Governance Policy for Rural Banks
sections.col1:
Data Governance Policy for Rural Banks

II. Data Governance: Inventory and Classification
Section 4. Inventory

Conduct a data inventory as a preliminary step to ensure the protection and integrity of personal data. Each unit must identify all documents that it administers.
sections.col2:
Section 5. Classification

After identifying the documents, units must classify them according to their sensitivity and risk level:

  • Public Data: Freely accessible documents to both internal and external parties.
  • Internal Data: Data posing low risk, accessible only within the bank's departments.
  • Confidential Data: Data posing medium risk, disclosed only to a limited number of authorized individuals.
  • Sensitive Personal Information: Data posing high risk, accessible only on a need-to-know basis by authorized personnel.

Data Governance Policy for Rural Banks

III. Data Governance: Responsibilities of Document Administrators and Users
Section 6. Document Classification

Heads of departments must ensure that all documents are classified according to this Policy and the bank's Data Classification Policy.

Section 7. Compliance with Policies

All employees are responsible for ensuring the privacy and confidentiality of the documents they use and process, adhering to the bank's Information Security Policy and Data Privacy Manual.

Section 8. Document Access

Department heads are responsible for determining authorized personnel for document access, creating access restrictions or guidelines based on the Data Classification Policy.
sections.col2:
Section 9. Document Storage

All units must provide secure storage for documents, ensuring that unauthorized persons cannot access them while allowing authorized personnel appropriate access.

Section 10. Document Disposal and Destruction

Documents should be retained only as long as necessary for legitimate purposes. When disposing of documents, ensure:

  • Documents are destroyed in a manner that data cannot be reconstituted (e.g., shredding).
  • No legal requirement exists for continued retention.
  • The bank has no foreseeable need for the document.
  • No data subject rights are violated.

sections.title: Best Practices of Organizations
sections.subheader: Sample Data Governance Policy for Rural Banks
sections.col1:
Data Governance Policy for Rural Banks

IV. Data Protection and Security Measures
Section 11. Back-up and Protection

Implement regular data backup procedures to ensure data availability and protection against loss.

Section 12. Security Incident and Personal Data Breaches

Establish a breach response team responsible for assessing and evaluating security incidents, including personal data breaches, and restoring data integrity.
sections.col2:
V. Policy Review and Support
Section 13. Policy Review

This Policy will be reviewed and updated annually or as necessary. Employees may submit suggestions for modifications to the Data Protection Officer for discussion.

This Data Governance Policy for rural banks is designed to ensure effective data management while protecting the privacy and security of customer information. By adhering to this policy, the rural bank can enhance operational efficiency, support data-driven decision-making, and comply with the Data Privacy Act of 2012.

sections.title: Emerging Trends
sections.subheader: In the Lens of the Philippines
sections.col1:
Here are the emerging trends in data governance in the Philippines, along with descriptions and examples of real banks implementing these practices:

Increased Regulatory Compliance

Organizations are focusing on compliance with data protection laws, such as the Data Privacy Act of 2012. This includes establishing frameworks to ensure adherence to legal requirements and mitigate risks associated with non-compliance.

Example:

Bank of the Philippine Islands (BPI) has established a comprehensive compliance framework, appointing data protection officers and conducting regular audits to ensure compliance with data protection regulations.
sections.col2:
Data Privacy Awareness

There is a growing awareness of data privacy among consumers and organizations. Businesses are investing in training programs and awareness campaigns to educate employees and customers about data privacy rights and responsibilities.

Example:

Union Bank of the Philippines has launched an initiative called Selyado 5.0 series to raise awareness about data privacy among its customers and employees, providing educational materials and conducting training sessions on data privacy rights.

sections.title: Emerging Trends
sections.subheader: In the Lens of the Philippines
sections.col1:
Here are the emerging trends in data governance in the Philippines, along with descriptions and examples of real banks implementing these practices:

Adoption of Data Governance Frameworks

Organizations are adopting formal data governance frameworks to manage data effectively. This includes defining roles, responsibilities, and processes for data management to ensure accountability and compliance.

Example:

Metrobank has implemented a formal data governance framework that outlines roles, responsibilities, and processes for managing data effectively, ensuring accountability and compliance with regulations.
sections.col2:
Integration of Data Analytics

The use of data analytics is becoming more prevalent in decision-making processes. Organizations leverage data analytics tools to derive insights from data, improve operational efficiency, and enhance customer experiences.

Example:

RCBC (Rizal Commercial Banking Corporation) leverages data analytics to enhance customer experiences and improve operational efficiency, using analytics to gain insights into customer behavior and preferences.

sections.subheader: In the Lens of the Philippines
sections.col1:
Here are the emerging trends in data governance in the Philippines, along with descriptions and examples of real banks implementing these practices:

Focus on Data Quality Management

There is an increasing emphasis on ensuring data quality and integrity. Organizations are implementing data quality management practices to validate, cleanse, and maintain accurate data.

Example:

Philippine National Bank (PNB) has implemented data quality management practices to ensure the accuracy and reliability of its data, including regular data validation and cleansing processes.
sections.col2:
Collaboration and Data Sharing

Public and private sectors are exploring collaborative approaches to data sharing. Initiatives aimed at sharing data for research, policy-making, and public service delivery are gaining traction, particularly in areas like health, education, and disaster response.

Example:

Land Bank of the Philippines collaborates with government agencies to share data for public service delivery, particularly in agricultural financing and disaster response.

Emergence of Data Literacy Programs

Organizations are recognizing the importance of data literacy among employees. Training programs are being developed to enhance employees' understanding of data governance, data management, and data analytics.

Example:

Security Bank has initiated data literacy programs to train employees on data governance, data management, and analytics, empowering staff to make informed decisions based on data insights.
sections.col2:
Cloud Adoption and Data Security

As more organizations migrate to cloud-based solutions, there is a heightened focus on data security and governance in cloud environments. Organizations are implementing security measures and governance policies to protect data stored in the cloud.

Example:

EastWest Banking Corporation has migrated to cloud-based solutions while implementing stringent data security measures and governance policies to protect customer data stored in the cloud.
